conceptual.question: Explain why the species-area relationship is a power law (S = cA^z) rather than a linear relationship.
hints: Think about what happens as area doubles

solution.summary: A power law reflects diminishing returns: doubling area doesn't double species because new habitat overlaps existing niches.
solution.detailed: Larger areas don't just contain more of the same habitats—they also contain rarer habitats and support viable populations of rarer species. The power law captures this saturation effect: each doubling of area adds a fixed percentage (not number) of new species.

computational.question: If S = 10×A^0.25 and an island has 1000 km², how many species are predicted?
If z = 0.3, reducing habitat area by 90% predicts what percentage of species lost?

solution.detailed: New/Original = 0.1^0.3 = 0.50. So 50% of species remain, meaning 50% are lost. This is a key formula for conservation planning.

applied.question: A forest fragment shrinks from 10,000 ha to 1,000 ha. Using z = 0.25, predict the proportion of species that will eventually be lost.

solution.detailed: Species remaining = (0.1)^0.25 = 0.562 = 56.2%. So 43.8% ≈ 44% will eventually be lost. This 'extinction debt' may take decades to fully manifest.

challenge.question: The Shannon diversity index is H' = -Σpᵢln(pᵢ). For a community with 2 equally abundant species, what is H'?

solution.detailed: H' = -[0.5×ln(0.5) + 0.5×ln(0.5)] = -[2 × 0.5 × (-0.693)] = 0.693. This equals ln(S) = ln(2), the maximum diversity for 2 species.
